newsitem.title: UK: Nobel winner adds anxieties to cloning debate.
newsitem.headline: Nobel winner adds anxieties to cloning debate.

text.p: Nobel peace prize winner Joseph Rotblat , adding his anxieties to the debate over the cloning of sheep, called on Tuesday for the creation of an international ethics committee to monitor scientific advances.
The veteran anti-nuclear campaigner said he feared advances in genetic engineering could pose as great a threat to humanity as the atom bomb.

"My worry is that other advances in human science may lead to other means of mass destruction more readily available than nuclear weapons. Genetic engineering is quite a possible area because of its frightful potentiality," Rotblat told BBC radio.
Scientists in Scotland said this week that they had cloned a sheep called Dolly using a ewe's egg cell and a mammary gland cell taken from a second ewe.
The development raised alarm that science has arrived at the brink of creating Frankenstein-style human clones, though Dolly's creators deny this.
U.S President Clinton has called on his national bioethics advisory panel to report on the legal and ethical implications within 90 days.
Rotblat said scientists themselves should form international ethics committees to regulate developments in all branches of science.
"However unpleasant it may be for scientists that science may have to be somehow controlled...I would like to see the setting up of an international ethical committee," said Rotblat.
The committee should vet projects before they are even started, said the 87-year-old nuclear physicist, who won the Nobel prize in 1995 for his campaign against the atom bomb he helped create.
Politicians, he said, simply did not understand science well enough to regulate it.
"I think it comes back to the scientists themselves to undertake this job."
